comments.commentBody: Republican authority? The Republican Party has no authority.
Shame!  No, the Founders never, ever envisioned an ignoramus like this driving the bus.

C'mon, Ginger, give the guy a break. If your enemies had threatened to murder you, I'll bet that you would take similar measures, maybe even conceal and carry a loaded one.  There's nothing like a death threat to jar one's perception of his/her vulnerability.

For those of you who don't live in WI or are unfamiliar with our Governor, the rest of us are spitting our coffee through our nose.
Mr Walker giving his fellow republicans advice about how to stand strong and take the high road is like listening to marital advice from OJ Simpson. None of us can forget the call from a Koch impersonator encouraging Walker to plant violent disrupters at rallies and hearing the governor affirm they had discussed that tactic. And after the governor published his book, UNINTIMIDATED, his fellow republicans leaking their disdain. They were left to wade through thousands of protesters alone while the governor was whisked through underground entryways by a team of state troopers. The state troopers, of course, excluded from the bill denying them union rights.

Mr Walker should follow his own advice and meet openly with out screening participants. He will find out just how far removed he is from the reality of his frightened WI residents. We can see more clearly the dangerous situation you and your tea party have created in Mr Trump. You, and consequently and all of us, could benefit from the reality check.
This is one of your best, Larry.
So if you live in a rich state, you are lucky but if you are not, tough luck!  This is not the solution chosen by Canada or many European countries.  As usual The U.S. shows how backward it is.
Governor, you're so clueless, I don't even know where to start.

I remember a stretch during the 2016 election campaign when the media, Times included, clearly appeared to do what they could to silence Bernie Sanders. Now here we are, with the Times giving dreck like Scott Walker a premium spot on the Op-Ed pages.

Forgive the Times, they know not what they do.....
Awww, John.  It's not their message, it's the Pope's message.  And the Pope's message is a reflection of the Jesus message:  of compassion, non-judgement and shared humanity.
Compassion trumps doctrine. Sounds like Jesus himself (remember the Good Samaritan?). Always timely; thank you!
If you could only comprehend how little the Pope cares about what you think.
How do you know that? Are there lots of jobs out there that are not being filled?  From what I hear, every time a job is listed, hundreds of people line up.

How will you touch their hand and look them in the eye if you just go through a non profit?  I think this is about giving right now when you see someone in need. It doesn't have to be much and the bulk of your giving can be through a non profit but this about giving others dignity and a helping hand when you can. If you wait to give to a non profit instead of helping the person in front of you, there is no guarantee  the money you eventually give to that non profit will help the person you ignore.

You don't have to help, this isn't a government mandate or a NYTimes cause.  This is the Pope suggesting a better way to engage with people having a hard time. If this is your response to other human beings than I think the poverty of your mind and heart is far greater than their poverty of material things. I hope things get better for you.
Someone recommends kindness, and your response is bitterness. How sad for you.
The Pope thinks you should treat human beings with compassion and respect. You may not like the messenger, but do you have a problem with the message?

Yes--well-- it's not enough. And in this coming cycle it will be less. So if you can spare anything , please take your opportunities, because what's humiliating is standing outside with your ask while people shuffle by with their heads down.

Those of us who are economically comfortable in life have a choice: give to institutions that provide support for the needy (and hold fancy fund raisers), or give directly to the downtrodden we encounter on the streets.  A donation to an institution is encouraged by current tax law--IT'S DEDUCTIBLE!!!!--even much of the cost of the fancy fund raisers.  Why not change the tax law so there is no deduction for contributions to "charitable organizations" at all?  Billions of additional dollars from increased tax collections would be available for government assistance to the needy.  And we would be able to give larger amounts directly to wretched fellow humans we encounter in our daily lives.

I don't get it. To everyone who says "He (or she) is just going to buy booze or drugs with it," well... wouldn't YOU? Maybe that's not the best possible choice of how to spend that money--but maybe it is. An instant of gratification in a cold, dark, likely foreshortened life is not nothing.

Worst case scenario, you've made someone happy for an instant. Whether that person is an addict, an alcoholic, a (God forbid!) scam artist, or a "deserving" poor person who is going to "properly" spend it on warm food or clothing... you've given that person a flash of happiness.

Nobody is forcing you to take that action, and you shouldn't feel guilty if you choose not to. But if you choose to... you made someone happy for a moment. You could surely have spent that time and treasure in a worse way.

Go in peace.

A San Francisco Chronicle columnist, Jon Carroll, had a practice -- during the winter holidays -- called the "The Untied Way". From his November 13, 2015 column, "When you give your clients a $20 bill, try to look them in the eyes. Ask them how they’re doing. Introduce yourself by name. Do anything to acknowledge your shared humanity." His advice was to take money from your ATM -- "Take as many ($20 bills) as you feel comfortable with, and then take a little more. It’s good if you feel a twinge; that means you’re doing it right." Though he encouraged this during the holidays, I am guessing any time of year would be welcome.

I have always remembered this practice and I don't always do it. I love this Pope and I have started giving more money to the homeless recently -- without judgment. The hardest part is having cash but now I have a bit more incentive to go to my ATM . Generosity is always good.
I always have a packaged snack (granola bar, orange,etc) in my bag for sharing.

Very interesting to read yesterday's Vietnam disastrous war with today's recent failures in the Middle East. Surely this detailed report of the backstory of the politics of Vietnam reminds us that then, like today, intel very sketchy. Along with the vying generasls, Ky and Thieu, LBJ had his own devils with which to deal; Westmoreland, McNamara, the Dulles brothers who brought their own brand of religious righteousness from their upbringing by Presbyterian missionaries in China, and all other exigencies of tremendous failures of understanding exacerabated when might is equated with right. I lost one friend in the war, a gung-ho husband/father who re-enlisted thrice and lost his life the third time. The military does not need more men or materiel unless in the service of superior knowledge of the enemy before war is waged.

The Western press was not there to naively point out the obvious shortcomings of Communism. The communists were their own best enemies when it came to this. If everyone in the South had thought the North a better solution then there wouldn't have been a war. In the end, the best reporting on the subject of the Northern victory could be said to have been the evidence of the "Boat People" who risked their lives to escape Communist Vietnam.
besides: had there been a practice of allowing reporters in the Communist north , no doubt then there might have been reporting abut the annual rice harvest and the condition of the dikes.

I've learned not to get excited about NYT history opinions. They are never connected to current events, save publication of a book. No surprise, here, then that repackaging his dissertation as a book is the stated reason for Sean Fear's fellowship at Dartmouth. I suppose a NYT's op-ed will help achieve that goal.

(http://dickey.dartmouth.edu/people/sean-fear)

Both generals were collaborating with an invading and occupying power, us. Which is why they were never going to be popular and those who march in a fifth column are rarely morally upstanding so the drug trafficking and lives of crime on both sides come as no surprise.

But the story has a happy ending. I was a regular visitor to HCM City till a few years ago and am happy to report that young Vietnamese admire America and the dream of students there is admission to a US school (the sky's the limit for parents to pay to for their kids to be coached for the various exams they need to pass in order to qualify for US scholarships).
